title: Airport lobby chief out as airline dispute finely poised
text:
Caroline Wilkie: Leaving at a crucial juncture. Jonathan Carroll

Following a publicity and lobbying blitzkrieg led by a united Qantas and Virgin, federal Cabinet is expected to rule by month’s end on whether to grant the airlines recourse to arbitration in their pricing disputes with Australian airports.

Alan Joyce and Paul Scurrah have ACCC chairman Rod Sims in their corner and his predecessor Graeme Samuel on their books, while the airports are brandishing a recent, favourable report by the Productivity Commission.

The airports’ major institutional investors include AustralianSuper, Colonial First State, the Future Fund, IFM and Macquarie, which are doggedly resistant to the introduction of an arbitration regime. Before their serious heavy hitters (Greg Combet, Heather Ridout, Ian Silk and Shemara Wikramanayake) were wheeled out to counter-attack the flying duopoly, the defence had been fronted by the Australian Airports Association, with HRL Morrison & Co’s asset management chief Steven Fitzgerald – a director of both Perth Airport and Queensland Airports – playing Rasputin and occasional covering fire provided by Canberra Airport’s Stephen “Badness” Byron, the literary stepson of CBR proprietor Terry Snow.

While the odds strongly favour a status quo victory, there are portents of discontent rising from the airports camp.

It was only two years ago, after all, that Australian Aviation nigh on broke the internet with the revelation that “AAA chief executive Caroline Wilkie will lead the organisation for at least five more years after receiving a contract extension.” You might well recall the palpable sense of relief across the nation that evening.
description: The odds strongly favour a status quo victory for the airports, yet there are portents of discontent rising from their camp.
